learning_outcomes.description: Explore, discuss, and apply theoretical and professional frameworks to real life communication cases, situations or problems; demonstrate knowledge of ethical and regulatory obligations linked with communication planning; and provide critical insights into contemporary trends, challenges and opportunities in the strategic communication/PR field and practice.

Develop problem solving capabilities to work individually and in groups with integrity, vision and courage; analyse a client brief, its aims, context and challenges; specific communication needs, and main stakeholders involved; and conduct feasible research methods whose findings will inform the campaign planning process.

Design meaningful, ethical, and effective strategic communication campaigns, programs or projects that propose: (a) clear goals and a holistic strategy; (b) 'SMART' objectives; (c) meaningful messaging; (d) culturally aware strategies and tactics to connect with relevant publics via interpersonal, community and digital communication techniques, tools and channels; and, (e) adequate evaluation methods that ensure that objectives are met.

Analyse, write, and present cases, projects and campaigns critically, strategically, and ethically by effectively researching and using library, digital, and industry resources; academic referencing styles; relevant rubrics and frameworks; and basic statistical information and/or data analytics.

assessments.task_description:
There will be 8 in-class writing tasks held in the lecture beginning in week 5 and concluding in week 13 (no writing tasks in week 8 due to industry guest lecture). This assignment asks students to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of some of the main strategic communication theories, concepts and professional themes discussed during the lectures in the previous weeks.You will be asked to briefly define and critically reflect on the topic or concept in your own words, in a handwritten task-sheet. You will be prepared to explain why the concept/topic is important to understand, or resolve, strategic communication projects in either industry or academic settings. You will also be prepared to link the concept to a 'real-life' example from lectures, tutorials, weekly readings and/or reliable media sites. You will be given 15 minutes (5 minutes to prepare and 10 mins to write) to provide a handwritten answer of a maximum of 250 words (5 X 250 = 1250 words in total). A list of key topics/concepts will be published on Blackboard (Assessment and Learning Resources section) in week 2.  You are expected to acknowledge or cite some of the ideas or authors that were discussed in previous classes or in the material you studied for the assignment. Therefore, reading, understanding and applying weekly material and participating in discussions in lectures and tutorials will be crucial to obtain the maximum grade. You may use an 'argument map' to develop your answer. This assessment evaluates students' own critical thinking and problem solving capabilities, engagement with course themes, and academic knowledge. More information about this assignment, list of main topics, and the rubric, will be posted to Blackboard in week 2.

IMPORTANT NOTE 1: There will be 8 opportunities to take the In-Class Writing Tasks, but you only need to take 5 (valued at 6 pts each), which together will form a maximum of 30 pts. If you do more than 5 Writing Tasks, we will select the best 5. This also means that you may miss up to 3 tasks without penalty. However, there will be NO opportunities to re-take individual papers, and no alternative assessment will be available (except in very specific circumstances, such as a ‘Disability Action Plan’ in place, or other genuine, well documented/supported reasons, such as medical issues, carer’s responsibility; sudden accident). So please, try to take as many as In-Class Writing Tasks as you can.

IMPORTANT NOTE 2: This assignment will be completed in person, during lectures, and is handwritten. You must bring your own pen(s) to the lecture. We will provide a task-sheet (paper) where you will write your name, student number, tutorial group and/or tutor’s name, and your answer. This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. So please engage with concepts, relevant authors, and themes from the beginning. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
This assignment (and the following ones) will be developed in groups of ideally 4 members (max 5) with whom you will continue to work for assignments 2 and 3. If you wish to work individually you will need to talk with the course coordinator and present genuine and well supported reasons.

The groups will send an email to the tutor and course coordinator with the full names of all team members and the name of the selected client. You will also write your names on a spread sheet that will be provided in tutorials. Teamwork involves full commitment to work with professionalism, executing allocated tasks in time, and respecting each other (see UQ group work guidelines and policy; also material on Bb). IMPORTANT: ALL students will self-enrol in a Blackboard group (instructions Bb). If you do not self enrol on Bb, you will not be able to submit or see your feedback and grades. Talk with the course coordinator and tutor if you have any issues in this regard.

The team will submit just one report (the same for all) via Blackboard, and will receive the same feedback and marks.

You may use a power point or word document to present this task. It may written using a mix of narrative style with dot points.

This task should include a graph/table of your SWOT, PEST, or other type of situation or contextual analysis as an illustration of your initial research work. To strengthen your situation analysis you may also include a graph with a communication audit and preliminary stakeholder map (optional but desirable). You are expected to include a reference list citing any material or secondary research used in the findings, e.g. reports, textbook frameworks (the ref. list will not included in the word count).

The task consists of two parts, 

(1) Written Report (5% - 500 words aprox.)

It will include:

      i.        Key elements of your client organisation, background, ‘the issue’, that is, client’s communication need and aim ('problem statement') (presented by the client in week 3).

     ii.        A Situation Analysis and/or PEST analysis, and a communication/media audit of your client organisation (this is preliminary background desk research).

    iii.        Identify the main communication problems/opportunities/challenges that your client organisation faces.

   iv.        Identify client's key stakeholder groups for this campaign specifically (stakeholder map may be included).

(2) Written Research Proposal (5% - 500 words approx.)

It will include:

      i.        Research proposal: Your research approach and methods will include a sample research item (e.g. type of secondary research; or a questionnaire for a survey; or a type of social media analysis; or other.

     ii.        The proposal should consist of feasible and realistic primary (quantitative or qualitative), and/OR secondary research methods; and/or social media analysis; and/or any mix of the above. Single methods are possible.

    iii.        Justify briefly why the method(s) proposed is/are appropriate to respond to the client's brief and target publics's attitudes, in the context in which they operate.

   iv.        Research schedule: A realistic timeline to complete the research task whose findings will inform A3. Feedback from your markers will help you advance towards the next step.

More informationon Blackboard (Course Resources and Assessment folders).

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
This third task, a Report, will continue to be prepared and submitted with your respective groups. After conducting the research proposed in assignment 2, A3 asks you to prepare a Report that will include:

  • (a) A list of research findings;
  • (b) An outline that will explain and justify why and how those findings will help you design the strategic communication plan for your client, and will enable you to frame, reframe, or refine the goal; main message(s); target publics;
  • (c) A minimum of one, preferably two preliminary SMART campaign objectives;
  • (d) A graph, table, or other schematic material whereby your group will display your research findings to your client and marker. This means that the Report will include some form of visualisation of your findings (you can use simple tables, graphs of any type, or other visuals).

Your report should have professional quality and creativity. For this assignment you will try to use the organisation's logo, colours, and overall look and feel (see style guide if available). Also, you should start creating your own agency/consultancy name and logo to receive feedback (this is a simulation, but it is important to be and look profesional).

Through this task and its Report students will demonstrate their understanding of the communication challenge or problem presented by the client. Students are expected to identify and reflect upon the importance of their research findings and the way those findings will inform their campaign plan (A4). Students will also demonstrate their problem solving capabilities in strategic communication projects or issues. 

IMPORTANT NOTE 1: For this report you will NOT include strategies and tactics YET (these will be included in the final Campaign Plan = A4).

assessments.task_description:
The fourth and final piece assessment, the Campaign Plan, consists of your Plan with the full proposal responding to the client. This task will be prepared, delivered and submitted by your group in two formats: (a) Pitch in Class on week 13 in tutorials (8 pts = 20%), listing the main elements of the campaign and highlighting a "star tactic"; and (b) Campaign Plan written and presented in slides submitted by the group via Blackboard (32 pts = 80%) on the due date (during Exam week 1). 

The Pitch:

  • In week 13 you will orally pitch the main elements of your plan and will display (in writing, digitally, graphically, audio-visually) ONE of the key tactics, assets, or collaterals that you will propose in your plan (the most important). Your group will have between 8 to10 mins including feedback. For example, a media release; a social media tactic; a website; a newsletter; brochure or flyer; a blog post for the client’s website; social media material; podcast or video; a PR event; a speech/conference; advocacy/lobby campaign; fundraising event; community relations/engagement plan and/or event, etc. In your pitch you will briefly justify why this is your main tactic, and how it will contribute to the success of your campaign for your client. The tactics and "star tactic' should aim to be effective, ethical, socially and contextually aware, displaying attractive and meaningful content that can potentially meet the client's communication need. This task values 8 pts (20% of 40, which is the overall grade for this assignment) which will be marked using the overall assignment rubric ('Plan/Design' item). Your pitch, will last between 8 and 10 mins and will be recorded for marking purposes. Please let your course coordinator and tutor know in writing if you would prefer not to be recorded by either voice or image so accomodations can be made. Reference any computational material used in your "star" tactic or other elements. You may bring 1-3 slides to pitch your plan in class.


All presentations will be recorded for marking purposes via recording facilities available where the assessment takes place (eg. ECHO360, Zoom, camera device). Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course. Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of: 

  • Moderation of marking;  
  • Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or  
  • Re-marking following a successful re-mark application. 


Your Campaign Plan ideally written in presentation slides format will include:

  1. Your consultancy name, professional-looking logo, and 'credentials' as PR/Comm consultant(s), and a cover letter addressed to your client (optional).
  2. Executive Summary with the main campaign elements proposed by your group.
  3. Your complete Campaign Plan where you will deploy: A refined/revised version of some of the elements already submitted for assignments 2 and 3, such as, (a) client's communication need/issue; (b) outline of research methods used and main findings; (c) main goal (intended outcome) of the specific campaign; (d) strategic approach; (e) key publics, (f) main message(s); (g) complete list of SMART objectives; and the following.
  4. New elements: 
  • Communication/action strategies and tactics (with the complete list of tactics).
  • Logistics: Campaign budget and schedule (two Gantt charts table or other).
  • Proposed evaluation methods (which may be used in the future, after execution) that will demonstrate that the objectives will be effectively met; ideally in a table vis-a-vis target publics and strategies.
  • Conclusion. A paragraph where you will briefly deploy the rationale, limitations, theoretical considerations (i.e. theoretical material that helped/inspired you in the planning process), used to inform the campaign proposal; and possible ethical/legal considerations that may arise from, or concern the campaign plan (if any) according to best practice frameworks; final recommendations (if any).
  • A reference list of any theories, frameworks, statistics from textbooks, reports, or online resources used in the planning, design and illustration of the Campaign, and other elements that may or may not be computational (e.g. the use of Canva, or other) which must be cited for integrity/ethical reasons (the ref. list will not be included in the word count). You will also reference your client's company or website.

Both, the Campaign Plan content and slides must aim at high a level of professional quality, creativity, and authenticity. All the elements in the Plan must respond to the client brief and campaign goal, and must be consistent with the client organisation's style guide. You will include the budget, schedule and evaluation methods (simulation) using tables/graphs for some of those items. Note that human writing and visuals are preferred to AI writing or images, which may look boring, repetitive and often lack creativity. You must not mention the client and its issues if you intend to use AI tools (if so you must reference and acknowledge its use). Overall, this is the task that will demonstrate your group's critical thinking and true problem solving capabilities, which are highly appreciated by the industry.

It is crucial that students take relevant MaPS training workshops, as well as Library and LinkedIn Learning workshops in advance, during the first weeks of the semester.

Activities: Selecting strategy(ies) and some tactics. groups propose mock "star tactic" and discuss in class. Compare and display in class AI strategies (prompted by some groups in the tutorials), with human strategies, critically discuss quality and results in each case.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13 Tutorial: Pitching your campaign plan

THE PITCH (8-10 mins per group, including feedback): Students will pitch their campaign plans and 'star' tactic ideas to receive feedback from the tutors. Bring a slide or two to the class. The pitch may receive up to 8 pts that will form part of the final assignment's grade (the Campaign Plan). The pitch will be brief (recorded, please indicate in writing if your do not wish to be recorded). More information on Blackboard.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
